addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

10 De
c
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L./
His dealinge w
th
Conte Maurice
for 2 prisoners to redeme
M
r
Winter
./

page.lettertext:
fol.273r
May it please yo
r
good L. What successe I
have had in
e suite of M
r
Winter, this bearer
his servant can informe yo
w
at large. I had
so firme a promise of Count Maurice, as I
could not any way request to have it more in
his favo
r
, to witte, That
e two Italian pri-
soners
Don Alfonso D'avalos
, and
Pedro Fran-
cesco
should not onely be staied to redeeme
M
r
Winter, but that he himself would use his
autoritie, in setting down what mony should
be paied
by
to
e Captaines, to whome the pri-
soners appertened: and that
e frindes of M
r
Winter, in disboursing
e said mony, should
take
e prisoners to themselves. To this effect
he gave his worde, not onely to me, but to
S
r
Francis Vere
, and that very often, and in sundrie
communications, w
t
suche tokens of willingnes,
as I could not desire, to be more assured by his
speeches. W
t
all he desired me to write
e same
unto her
Ma
tie
from whome I was willed to
move him, That for
e weakening of
e Ene-
mies purposes in
France,
there might not any
prisoner of q
a
litie and service, of those that
were taken in
e late encounter at
Arnham,
be released for a time. Moreover I
shewed him after,
at I had certified her Hig
nes
of his honorable dealing towardes M
r
Winter:
and
at I was assured it would be kindly
accepted, for
e special services, w
ch
were done
by his father unto her, and for
e hope
at she
conceaved,
at his sonne would succeede him in
fol.273v
vertu and valo
r
. I told him besides, that
e gentleman had caused his mony to
be
made
to
Middlebourgh,
to pay for
e prisoners, and
had sent hither to
at end a couple of his ser-
vants. All this notw
t
standing upon
e
soddaine, w
t
out geving any notice to S
r
Francis
Vere, or to me, he hath released Don Alfonso
and sent him away. The day before his
departure being secretly informed of this in-
tention of
e Count, I went of purpose unto
him, and signified what I heard, putte him in
minde of his promise, and of that w
ch
I had writ-
ten to her Ma
tie
upon it. For yo
r
L. I hope
receaved those letters w
ch
I writte of
at mater.
His answear was,
at
e prisoners had bin
long detened, and seing in all this time they
were able to doe nothing for M
r
Winters deli-
verance, upon suite made unto him by
e
Mar-
quis of Guasto
, he had promised to dismisse Don
Alfonso: who also promised upon his hono
r
,
at he would imploy all his best frindes and
meanes to procure M
r
Winters libertie.
Whereto I replied
at if Don Alfonso had bin
putte into o
r
handes, according to promise, there
might better effectes have folowed of his ende-
vo
rs
: but being used heere w
t
all courtesie
and hono
r
, and being secretly promised a
great while sins (for so I was advertised by
those
at knew it) that he should be enlar-
ged, there was no hope
at ether he or his
frindes would greatly care for M
r
Winter.
And as for his promise to doe any thing nowe,
fol.274r
it had no apparance of any successe. I told
him in conclusion,
at he had given his worde
unto me, w
ch
I had signified to her Ma
tie
to de-
liver bothe
e prisoners to M
r
Winters frindes,
that they had made over their mony to certaine
marchants of Middlebourgh, where it had laien
a long time to their very great charges, and
that M
r
Winter, by reason of his promise, had
neglected all other meanes to procure hi s re-
demption. In w
ch
respect I should be sorie,
that her Ma
tie
should finde so just a cause to be
offended w
t
his dealing. For mine owne part
I could doe no otherwise but advertise it home,
and leave unto him self
e salving of his hono
r
wherein I pressed him so neere,
at he came to
this point,
at her Ma
tie
he was sure, would be
pleased w
t
his answear, w
ch
he would signifie
himself by letter unto her: and sent me therupon
e letter heereinclosed. Wherof I knowe not
e
teno
r
, but I have certified truly, howe the
mater hath bin caried. He hath
urged me muche, to take
e other prisoner, al-
leaging his credit w
t
e D. of Parma, and
e
report of his wealth, for yelding a rounde
ransome farre above
e summe, w
ch
should
be paied for him heere. But forasmuche as
bothe
e prisoners, as he himself was persuaded
would not ballance M
r
Winter, in
e Enemies
account, this other man alone would serve to
litle purpose, unles it were to make a benefit,
to selle him againe: w
ch
I esteemed, as I told
him a mechanical consideration, and nothing
to
e mater w
ch
was sought by M
r
Winter.
fol.274v
And thus I ended w
t
e Count, whose proceeding
in this mater, doth seeme so very strange,
and w
t
out all excuse, to all
at understand it,
as I finde him greatly discommended, in
every mans judgement.
And thus referring
to
e bearer, w
at
soever is omitted, I take my
humble leave. From
e Hage. 10 De
c
1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
